channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: Ukrainian Fighters Battle to Hold Kyiv
item.description: The Ukrainian capital is transformed into a battle zone as Volodymyr Zelensky, the president, warned against false reports of his demise. NATO leaders said more troops would be deployed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene Saturday morning after fighting in the Ukrainian capital, Kyiv.

item.title: At the Polish Border, Tens of Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: They have been warmly welcomed in a country whose border guards last year beat back mostly Afghan and Middle Eastern migrants with batons.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Zapotochna with her gravely ill son, Arthur, after crossing the Ukrainian-Polish border on Friday. “We are still living in the 21st century, I hope,” Ms. Zapotochna said.

item.title: ‘Abrupt Changes’: China Caught in a Bind Over Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: China has presented itself as a defender of sovereign independence. But its reluctance to denounce Russia’s aggression forces it into an awkward position.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, this month in Beijing.

item.title: In Video, a Defiant President Zelensky Says, ‘We Are Here’
item.description: The 44-year-old president of Ukraine videotaped himself in Kyiv as Russian forces closed in on the capital, vowing to fight them to the end.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Ukraine Presidency, via AFP/— Getty Imagess
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky early Friday in Kyiv, in a photo provided by Ukraine’s government.

item.title: An Iranian Director’s Rule: ‘Always Focus on Ordinary People’
item.description: Asghar Farhadi, who has won two Oscars, says stories about the rich and famous “are not part of my emotional bank.”
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Asghar Farhadi, the Iranian filmmaker, in West Hollywood, Calif., in January.

item.title: Chernobyl Plant Is Unharmed Despite Russian Invasion of Ukraine, Scientists Say
item.description: The nation’s 15 operating reactors have also been assessed as safe — at least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: The site of the fourth reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine in 2017.

item.title: European Leaders Agree to a Second Wave of Russia Sanctions
item.description: The E.U. agreed to freeze the assets of President Putin and foreign minister Sergey Lavrov, while other measures will hit Russia’s access to technology
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, in the early hours of Friday after a meeting with European leaders in Brussels.

item.title: Ukraine War Strains North Africa Economies
item.description: Egypt imports most of its wheat from Russia and Ukraine, and is looking for alternative suppliers. And Tunisia was struggling to pay for grain imports even before the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Aida Alami
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Baking bread in Saqqara, near Giza, Egypt.

item.title: How Russia Attacked Ukraine and What Happens Next
item.description: Explosions thundered in Ukrainian cities shortly after President Vladimir V. Putin declared the start of a “special military operation.”
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A building was hit in the town of Chuguiv, eastern Ukraine, on Thursday as Russian forces attacked the country.

item.title: What Does Russia Want in Ukraine? A Full Guide
item.description: Here’s a guide to the causes behind a conflict that has just become a major military clash, and what’s at stake for Russia, the U.S. and NATO.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Richard Pérez-Peña and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier on Wednesday in the eastern part of the country. Tensions between Ukraine and Russia have been simmering since 2014.

item.title: Biden Targets Russia With Strategy of Containment, Updated for a New Era
item.description: President Biden’s plan to counter Russia faces obstacles in an interconnected world. Russia also has a new, if not very enthusiastic, partner in standing up to the West: China.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden and Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, in Geneva last year. Mr. Biden vowed this week to make Mr. Putin a “pariah on the international stage.”

item.title: Bappi Lahiri, India’s ‘Disco King,’ Dies at 69
item.description: He helped popularize the genre with some of the country’s biggest hits of all time, including “I Am a Disco Dancer.”
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:credit: Anshuman Poyrekar/Hindustan Times via Getty Images
item.media:description: Bappi Lahiri in 2011 at his home in Mumbai. He grew up idolizing Elvis for his style and ultimately became known for his own flair — tinted sunglasses, shiny jackets and mounds of gold jewelry.

item.title: Surviving Migrants at Greek Border Say They Were Left to Die
item.description: The four men recalled a night of exhaustion, cold and fear when 19 died after being forced across the Turkish border.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the area near Ipsala, Turkey, where several of the 19 migrants who died earlier this month were found.

item.title: Missile Hits a Kyiv Residential Building [Video]
item.description: The missile hit a building about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Brenna Smith, Malachy Browne and Sarah Kerr

item.title: On Both Sides of Korean Peninsula, Eyes on Washington's Response to Russia
item.description: North Korea might decide it’s time to resume weapons tests, to gain more diplomatic leverage with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Watching coverage of the invasion of Ukraine in a Seoul train station on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Ties May Hurt Thousands of European Companies
item.description: Thousands of European companies that have operations in Russia may face collateral damage as Western sanctions aim to penalize Russia’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moscow’s International Business Centre last year. Many European banks and companies have operations and partnerships in Russia.

item.title: Empire State Building, Eiffel Tower Use Lights to Show Ukraine Support
item.description: The landmarks include the World Trade Center, the Eiffel Tower and more.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: The Empire State Building lit in the colors of the Ukrainian flag on Friday.

item.title: Russia Vetoes UN Security Council Resolution Calling on it to Withdraw from Ukraine
item.description: Eleven countries voted in favor of the U.S.-backed measure, and three abstained.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Canada Approves a Second Vaccine Made Without mRNA Technology
item.description: The clearance given to a plant-based offering developed by Medicago of Quebec City only covers people ages 18 to 64.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A scientist working in one of Medicago’s laboratories in Quebec City last year.

item.title: Ukraine Girds for Kyiv Attack Amid Signs of Slowing Russian Advance
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Russia’s Assault in Ukraine Slows After an Aggressive Start
item.description: The invading forces have faced stiff resistance, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could quickly send in more troops, Pentagon officials said.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A residential building was hit by missiles in southern Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, on Friday.

item.title: ‘I’m Ready’: Ukraine’s Civilians Take Up Arms
item.description: Volunteer fighters armed with assault rifles patrolled central Kyiv on Friday, ready to defend their country.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey, Taras Ratushnyy, Mark Boyer and Alexandra Eaton
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for the New York Times

item.title: Maryland Lifts Statewide School Mask Mandate
item.description: The decision gives local school districts the power to decide whether to require face coverings.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Rosem Morton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zia Hellman, a teacher, helps her student, Averie Colvin, 5, at Walter P. Carter Elementary/Middle School in Baltimore.

item.title: How the U.S. and Europe Are Targeting Putin With Sanctions
item.description: The new penalties are a provocative step given how rarely governments, including the United States, take aim at foreign leaders.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators at the White House protested on Friday against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: Eurovision Bars Russia From This Year’s Song Contest
item.description: “The inclusion of a Russian entry in this year’s contest would bring the competition into disrepute,” the organizers said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Manizha, the Russian representative in the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest, at the grand finale in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

item.title: A Canadian Leader with Ukrainian Roots Ranks Putin as One of Most ‘Reviled European Dictators.’
item.description: Canada has a large population with Ukrainian roots, including Chrystia Freeland, the deputy prime minister, whose interest in Ukrainian independence dates to the Soviet era.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Canada’s deputy prime minister and minister of finance, Chrystia Freeland, in the House of Commons in Ottawa this month.

item.title: Far-Right Militias in Europe Plan to Confront Russian Forces
item.description: The apparent mobilization of far-right groups could be problematic for the Ukrainian government
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Azov Battalion leading military exercises for civilians amid the threat of a Russian invasion, in Kyiv, this month.

item.title: New York City Schools Will Lift Outdoor Mask Mandate
item.description: Masking inside the city’s public schools will still be required, as is the case across the state, but not outside on school grounds.
item.dc:creator: Precious Fondren and Jeffery C. Mays
item.media:credit: Dieu-Nalio Chéry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Starting Monday, New York City public school students and staff members will no longer have to wear masks outdoors on school grounds. An indoor school mask mandate remains in place statewide.

item.title: Russia Will Limit Access to Facebook, A Major Platform for Dissent
item.description: Since President Vladimir V. Putin launched his attack on Ukraine, many Russians have taken to social media to express their anger.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman checked her phone on the Moscow subway in 2020.

item.title: ‘I’ll Stand on the Side of Russia’: Pro-Putin Sentiment Spreads Online
item.description: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Donald J. Trump at a meeting in 2019.

item.title: As Troops Battle Outside Kharkiv, Residents Shelter Underground
item.description: Ukrainian troops dug in around the nation’s second-largest city a day after a fight to push back advancing Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: Putin Claims Russia Has Been Fighting ‘Nationalist Groups,’ Not The Ukrainian Army
item.description: Russian state television aired brief remarks by Mr. Putin as he spoke by video to his Security Council.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir V. Putin entering a meeting with members of Russia’s Security Council via a video link in Moscow, on Friday.

item.title: ‘The world was in monochrome’: a Broadway conductor on his ongoing recovery from long Covid.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Fram at his gym in December, after discovering that pushing himself with long walks and other exercise was making matters worse.

item.title: Pope Francis Told to Sit Out Ceremonies Because of Knee Pain
item.description: A doctor recommended that Francis should take “a period of greater rest.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving to attend his weekly general audience in the Paul VI Hall at the Vatican on Wednesday.

item.title: Sanctions Aim to Put Pressure on Russia After Invasion
item.description: Several countries and the European Union have imposed a variety of sanctions in response to Vladimir V. Putin’s decision to invade Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the Kremlin and St. Basil’s Cathedral in Moscow earlier this month. A range of sanctions have been imposed on Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: The Pacific Spiny Lumpsucker Is Armed to the Teeth
item.description: The diminutive predator is a terrible swimmer but thrives in the intertidal zone thanks to odd evolutionary adaptation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Rapp Learn

item.title: A Humorous Ukrainian Writer, With Nothing to Laugh About
item.description: Andrey Kurkov wrote about fighting between Russia and Ukraine long before Thursday’s invasion. But now, more than ever, he wants to explain it to the world.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: “Until several weeks ago, I didn’t think it was realistic,” the writer Andrey Kurkov said about Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. His 2018 novel “Grey Bees” was set in the earlier Ukraine-Russia conflict.

item.title: U.S. First Time Vaccination Rates Are At a New Low
item.description: As the country is on course to live with the coronavirus, the vaccination drive is vanishing.
item.dc:creator: Ada Petriczko
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: The number of people receiving vaccines in the United States is the lowest since the vaccines were first introduced over a year ago.

item.title: Russia Confirms It Controls Chernobyl Plant
item.description: Russia’s Defense Ministry said it was working with Ukrainian guards to ensure the safety of the former plant, while Ukraine said Russian forces were holding the facility’s personnel hostage.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Chernobyl, Ukraine, last month. After a 1986 nuclear accident, it now lies inside a 1,000-square-mile exclusion zone in northern Ukraine.

item.title: Why the Sanctions Against Russia Aren’t Tougher
item.description: Why aren’t the U.S. and its allies imposing tougher sanctions?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian military aircraft was shot down near Kyiv.

item.title: Covid has surged through nursing homes in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Hong Kong's elderly have been the hardest hit by Covid-19, as many remain unvaccinated.

item.title: Russia Says It Won't Enter Talks Until Ukraine Stops Fighting
item.description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey Lavrov, made clear that Russia was seeking to topple the democratically elected government of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, in Moscow on Friday, when he said Russia could not recognize a government that “persecutes and uses methods of genocide against its own people”.

item.title: Nils van der Poel Gives Away His Medal to Protest Beijing’s Abuses
item.description: In a rare rebuke of Beijing, Nils van der Poel, a speedskater, handed one of his gold medals to the daughter of Gui Minhai, a book publisher imprisoned in China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Tariq Panja and Andrew Das
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Swedish speedskater Nils van der Poel handing his Olympic gold medal to Angela Gui, the daughter of an imprisoned Chinese bookseller, in Cambridge, England, on Thursday.

item.title: Biden Officials Repeatedly Urged China to Help Avert War in Ukraine
item.description: Americans presented Chinese officials with intelligence on Russia’s troop buildup in hopes that President Xi Jinping would step in, but were repeatedly rebuffed.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden participated in a video summit with President Xi Jinping of China in November.

item.title: A Key Inflation Gauge Is Still Rising, and War Could Make It Worse
item.description: The Federal Reserve’s preferred measure is at a four-decade high. Rising gas prices tied to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine could push it up further.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rising prices for food, rent and gas are shaking consumer confidence.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A special edition on the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Ukrainian military vehicles on the side of the road outside Severodonetsk, eastern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Covid Drove More Australians Away From Cities. Will They Go Back?
item.description: As restrictions ease, will the appeal of fewer people, a lower risk of transmission and more personal space prove to be enduring?
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:description: A Gold Coast beach in January.

item.title: The White House releases a plan to help people who are especially vulnerable to Covid-19.
item.description: The plan involves making masks and tests more accessible, but has been criticized by some disability advocates for not going far enough to protect the most vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Morris
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden administration has said they will address the disparities experienced by immunocompromised people or those with disabilities such as Toby Cain, whose lymphatic cancer diagnosis makes her especially vulnerable to Covid.

item.title: The C.D.C. will soon loosen indoor mask guidelines, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Libby March for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most people may be able to go without masks in public indoor spaces under new guidelines.

item.title: See Photos on the Ground in Ukraine
item.description: Photographers spread around Ukraine captured a populace struggling with uncertainty and fear in the face of a military invasion.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Biden Hits Russia With Broad Sanctions for Putin’s War in Ukraine
item.description: The penalties will affect Russia’s biggest banks, its weapons industry, its largest energy company and families close to President Vladimir V. Putin. The country’s stock market has plummeted.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Ana Swanson
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Russian invasion forces penetrate Ukraine on multiple fronts and close in on Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Families boarding evacuation trains in Kramatorsk on Thursday evening, bound for Kyiv, the capital, and Lviv, the largest city in western Ukraine.

item.title: Trump Praises Putin, Leaving Republicans in a Bind
item.description: G.O.P. leaders, while condemning Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, were silent on comments made by the former president. Some figures on the right amplified them.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick, Maggie Astor and Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with President Donald J. Trump in June 2019.

item.title: As Ukrainians Flee Russian Assault, Coronavirus Rides Along
item.description: The fighting in Ukraine’s east is forcing a hurried mass migration that leaves little room for pandemic considerations.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: People waited for trains leaving the main train station in Kramatorsk, in eastern Ukraine, shortly after Russia invaded the country on Thursday morning.

item.title: Russia Batters Ukraine With Artillery Strikes as West Condemns Invasion
item.description: Explosions were reported over Kyiv, the capital. Several countries announced severe new sanctions, as Vladimir Putin remained resolute about his decision to invade.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Eric Schmitt and Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Families boarding evacuation trains in Kramatorsk Thursday evening, bound for Kyiv, the capital, and Lviv, the largest city in western Ukraine.

item.title: Biden Denounces Putin's Actions in Ukraine
item.description: President Biden announced new sanctions but conceded that they would not immediately prevent President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia from continuing his military assault.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden on Thursday called the invasion “a brutal assault on the people of Ukraine without provocation, without justification, without necessity.”
